docs.lead_paragraph: IN a small beige hotel room in Midtown, Janis Ian was warming up. Sitting on a twin bed, she pulled her new guitar out of its white, velvet-lined case. ''Eight weeks old,'' she said. ''It's a baby.'' The baby twanged. Bottles -- some containing water, some not -- lined the windowsill. Luggage was piled on the bed behind her. The following night she would do two shows at Joe's Pub, but now she was preparing for a laid-back gig at Jim Caruso's Cast Party, an open jam-style show at Birdland. Even after more than 40 years in the music business, Ms. Ian, a Grammy winner and seminal singer-songwriter who lives in Nashville, needs a rehearsal.

headline.main: A NIGHT OUT WITH -- Janis Ian; At Fifty-Five

docs.abstract: Long-time folk singer Janis Ian describes her 40-year career in music business and possible retirement; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your reports about Massachusetts' health reform legislation treat politicians' overblown claims as gospel. The legislation completely ignores one-third of the uninsured, dismissing the Census Bureau's estimate that 748,000 lack coverage in Massachusetts in favor of an estimate of 500,000 derived from a phone survey.
docs.abstract: Drs David U Himmelstein and Steffie Woolhandler letter holds that reports in New York Times about Massachusetts' health reform legislation treat politicians' overblown claims as gospel

docs.lead_paragraph: HANK McKINNELL, the chairman and chief executive of Pfizer, the $51 billion-a-year pharmaceutical company, and chairman of the Business Roundtable, an organization of chief executives, argues that C.E.O.'s are increasingly committed to socially responsible corporate behavior because it is essential to profitability. Here are excerpts from a conversation: Q. How does the social and political environment around you affect your ability to make money? A. If we're seen by the community as providing goods and services that enable people to live a happy, long life, society will want us to succeed. If they see what we're doing in education and sports programs, that's important. Otherwise, society will hope that we will fail.

headline.main: The Impact of Image On the Bottom Line

docs.abstract: Excerpts from interview with Pfizer chairman-chief executive Hank McKinnell, who is chairman of Business Roundtable, on chief executive officers who are increasingly committed to socially responsible corporate behavior because it is essential to profitability; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: The chief executive of Pfizer argues that C.E.O.'s are increasingly committed to socially responsible corporate behavior because it is essential to profitability.

docs.lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eliot Spitzer assailed the budget proposals of Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature in a speech on Saturday, saying the state would be left with large future deficits, a squandered surplus and ballooning problems, including a sprawling Medicaid program. But he continued to face pointed attacks from his Democratic rival for governor, Nassau County Executive Thomas R. Suozzi, who accused Mr. Spitzer of failing to take on Medicaid fraud and reform. Mr. Suozzi, in his own speech, detailed an agenda to cut state spending, to finance reductions in property taxes.

headline.main: At Budget Event, Spitzer and Suozzi Trade Harsh Words About Albany

docs.abstract: Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer, candidate for governor of New York, attacks Gov George E Pataki's budget proposals, saying state will be left with large future deficits, squandered surplus and ballooning problems, including Medicaid; his rival for Democratic nomination, Nassau County Exec Thomas R Suozzi, says Spitzer is failing to take on Medicaid fraud and reform; both men appeared with two Republican candidates, William Weld and John Faso, at conference held by Citizens Budget Commission in Armonk, NY; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Massachusetts legislators have put forth what appears to be a positive step toward ending the nightmare of the medically uninsured. But it sidesteps the single-payer approach, which has been successful in other industrialized countries but is not politically palatable here.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The new health insurance law in Massachusetts is in effect a new tax on what should be as free as public education. It forces individuals, by government decree, to put dollars directly into the pockets of insurance and drug companies and H.M.O.'s.
